position.marginalia_text: Malo dare diues, quàm mendicare pauper.
Malo ridere pauper, quàm plorare diues.

marginalia.translation: I prefer to give riches as a rich man than beg for alms as a poor man. I prefer to laugh as a poor man than weep as a rich man.

position.marginalia_text: ( Homo simplex est, qui non statim audet ( seria, efficaciaq[ue] loqui ( in quouis publico, aut regio Concilio.

marginalia.translation: A man is simple when he does not immediately dare to engage in earnest endeavours and to utter effective discourses in whatever public or royal council.
Exquisite things are troublesome, unless they are unencumbered.
The lion and the basilisk fear the rooster.

position.marginalia_text: Semper ad rem aptissimè: ad punctum strictissimè.

marginalia.translation: Always most adapted to the thing at hand, always most directly to the point.

position.marginalia_text: Quisq[ue] artifex in suo Hempispha[e]rio. In tota Spha[e]ra Polytechnus. Vrso in suo Epicyclo.

marginalia.translation: Whoever is in their own hemisphere is a master artist. Whoever is in the whole sphere is a polytechnus. Urso in his epicycle.

position.marginalia_text: Placent etiam epigrammata Martialias, et Politiani; Mori, et Heuodi; propter argutias.

marginalia.translation: Due to their cleverness, I also like the epigrams of Martial and Poliziano, Moore and Heywood.

position.marginalia_text: Ante omnia, apophthegmata Plutarchi, ,et Laertij ad vnguem: cum Gandini Stratagematis: et technis Oeconomicis Aristotelis, etiam ad vnquem.

marginalia.translation: Before everything, learn the aphorisms of Plutarch and Laertius by heart, together with the strategems of Gandinus and the Economic crafts of Aristotle, also by heart.

position.marginalia_text: Peritissimi vita[e] ciuilis pragmatici, duas semper exercent internas Virtutes, prudentiam, et fortitudinem: duas profitentur externas, temperantia, et iustitia.

marginalia.translation: Pragmatic men most skilled in civil life always practice two internal virtues, prudence and strength. Two external virtues are always shown openly, temperance and justice.
